text:
This video was made possible by Dollar Shave
Club.

Get your first starter set for just $5 at
DollarShaveClub.com/HAI.
This video is about bricks.

Now, something you might not know about bricks
is that they often have an indentation on
one side which is referred to as the frog.

Among bricklaying enthusiasts, there’s this
big debate as to whether you should lay the
brick frog up or frog down.

If you go on bricklaying forums, you’ll
see endless spirited debate on frog orientation

and that really… ok, that should be enough
to get the FBI agent assigned to my channel
to click away.

That was necessary because today we’re spilling
some secret government tea.

There are few certainties in life: death,
taxes, that Denver airport is home to the

secret underground liar of the lizard people,
and that snitches get stitches.

Considering that’s the case, you might want
to figure out how to sew through plastic and

inkjet cartridges… because your printer
is tattling on you… and it’s been doing
so for years.

Not only have printers been putting secret
codes on every page for decades, but for over
20 years, nobody knew.
Well, nobody except the government, that is.

They definitely knew about it, because that’s
the whole point—the codes are there to allow
investigators to track counterfeiters.

You see, back in the 1980s, a lot of things
were happening.

Rubix's cubes were all the rage, walls were
getting torn down, and people were sitting

bored in their houses for hours on end because
there wasn’t a fast, free, and easy way

to watch dozens of professional-quality videos
about bricks.

Also, the color photocopier was starting to
get pretty popular and when that happened,

the world government, based in DC, understandably
started to get pretty worried that people
would use those color copiers to copy money.

After all, before that, to copy money you
had to either have own your own printing press

or be really, really good at drawing George
Washington’s weird hair.

The Xerox company wanted to assure the government
that there was no way that somebody would

be able to use their copiers to copy money
so they secretly developed a way to include,

on every single printed piece of paper, a
map back to the source.
The key?
Tiny yellow dots.

Still today, nearly every printed piece of
paper is covered with tiny yellow dots that

are so small—with a diameter of 1/10 of
a millimeter—that they’re almost invisible
to the naked eye.

They were intentionally made yellow so that
when printed on white paper, nobody would
notice them.

In fact, even if you know they’re there,
the only way to see them clearly is to shine

an LED light on the page and then look very
carefully using a magnifying glass which is

probably why nobody noticed them for so long
because, like, why would you do that.
That would be weird.

But if you do, in fact, do that, you’ll
notice a bunch of dots that look randomly

scattered across the page, but the placement
isn’t random at all.
It’s a code.

When the public found out about these dots,
it didn’t take long for people to break

the code and figure out exactly how these
little yellow dots had managed to report so
much information to the government.
Here’s how it worked.

The dots were printed in a 7-by-15 grid, and
each column represented something different,

like the time, or the date, or the serial
number.

Under each column, a number was written in
a version of binary code that used dots instead
of ones.

It’s can be a little confusing, but here’s
a breakdown.

The numbers were represented by what’s called
a 7-bit counter, that can represent any number
between 1 and 127.

There are seven spots in a seven-bit counter,
and each represents a different number—64,

You put a dot or a one or something in a spot
out of seven to add that number to the total.

So if I want to make the number one, I would
write 0000001.
If I wanted to write 2, I would write 0000010.
If I wanted to write 73, I would write 1001001.

You can combine these numbers in a way to
make every number up to 127.
That’s how these codes worked.

Each column had a number that was spelled
out in binary code.

The first and fourth columns showed what time
it was.

The fourth column showed the hour, and the
first column showed the minute.

So in this example, the fourth column says:
add 8 and 4.
That’s 12.
So we know it was 12 something.
The first column says, add 32, 16, and 2.
That’s 50.

So we know the time the page was printed was
12:50.
The next columns showed the date.

Column 6 showed the day, 7 showed the month,
and 8 showed the year.
So we know the day was 16+4+1, or 21.
We know the month was 4+2, so 6.
And we know the year was 4+1, or 5.
In this case 5 means 2005.

And then columns 11-14 showed the serial number
in reverse order.

I won’t do all the math all over again because
that was already enough for the week, but

in this example the serial number would be
21, 05, 28, 57.

Aaaand, nobody every figured out what the
15th column does.
So let’s just assume that it [censored.]

These grids of code aren’t just printed
once per page.

They’re printed about 150 times on each
sheet of paper but even still, nobody noticed
these dots for two decades.

But then, in 2004, rumors started to swirl,
and PC World broke the news that your printer
was a double agent.

Now we don’t know exactly how many counterfeiters
the government managed to catch in that time,

but we do know, according to one counterfeiting
specialist with the US Secret Service, that
the codes have been, “extraordinarily helpful.”
You know what’s also extraordinary helpful?

Always having a razor blade, stick of deodorant,
tube of toothpaste, tub of hair gel, stick

of chapstick, bar of soap, and every other
grooming product stocked consistently in your
home so you have it when you need it.

Well then, it’s dan-diddly-doodle good that
Dollar Shave Club exists.

How it works if that you build a box of every
grooming product you need and then decide

how often you want them to deliver it to keep
you stocked.

I tried their toothbrush and toothpaste, shampoo
and conditioner, and shave butter and razor,
and they were all really high quality.

I probably had my cleanest and smoothest shave
ever with their shaving kit.

What’s even more exciting than that, though,
is that you can try them out by getting a

starter set for just $5 only at DollarShaveClub.com/HAI
and you’ll also be supporting HAI while
you’re at it.
